awd_titl_txt: RUI: Scaffold or Assembly Line: How Does Atg11 Organize its Binding Partners for the Initiation of Selective Autophagy?
awd_abstract_narration:
The subject of this research project is selective autophagy, a cellular clean-up and recycling process used by animals, plants and fungi to maintain cellular function. This project will improve America's competitiveness by contributing to the education of a diverse and technically literate workforce. It will create a research-rich learning environment for biochemistry students at Eastern Michigan University, a primarily undergraduate institution that serves a racially and socioeconomically diverse population of students. It will do this by supporting a cutting-edge research program that will directly engage ~10-12 undergraduate and Master's level students in mentored scientific research projects as well as creating semester-long guided research experiences for ~30-36 additional undergraduates as part of a research-based senior-level biochemistry lab. Multiple studies have shown that the most effective way for students to learn science is by participating in authentic scientific research. Therefore, this project will not only advance our fundamental understanding of the natural world but also train the next generation of scientists.  

Selective autophagy targets damaged or unwanted cellular components, such as toxic protein aggregates or malfunctioning mitochondria, and delivers them to the vacuole/lysosome where they are destroyed and their constituents recycled. This research focuses on understanding the basic mechanisms of selective autophagy in the model organism baker's yeast. One of the key proteins that guides the process of selective autophagy is Atg11, which interacts with a number of other autophagy proteins and organizes them into a functional protein complex. This research will explain how Atg11 organizes this complex by determining the characteristics of Atg11's interactions with its protein partners. Specifically, it will determine whether Atg11can bring together all of its partners at once, in the manner of a scaffold, or whether it interacts with them one at a time, in the manner of an assembly line. This information will help us to understand how selective autophagy actually occurs, not only in yeast but also many other organisms that share a similar machinery, including humans.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Scientific advancements: investigating the mechanisms of autophagy

Autophagy is a medically important process that keeps us healthy by getting rid of toxic debris within our cells such as damaged organelles, protein aggregates and invading pathogens.  In this way it helps prevent disease, including neurodegenerative diseases such as Parkinson's and Alzheimer's as well as infectious diseases and some cancers.  This process is poorly understood, but has been best studied in baker's yeast, which serves as a model for other eukaryotes, including humans.  A protein called Atg11 is central to the most selective types of autophagy in yeast, but we do not know the structure of Atg11 or how it organizes the other proteins that it interacts with to initiate selective autophagy.  A different protein, Atg7, is the first step in another pathway critical for autophagy; Atg7's structure is known, but the overall role of that pathway in the autophagy process is less understood.

We have advanced our understanding of both of these proteins, and autophagy overall.  For Atg11, we systematically mutated amino acids within a central region of the protein to find those few that are critical for its ability to bind its protein partners and initiate selective autophagy (see figure; tyrosine 565 proved to be most important).  For Atg7, we discovered that cells with insufficient amounts of Atg7 generated autophagosomes that are both fewer and smaller than those with normal amounts of Atg7.  This was surprising, because Atg8-PE, which had been thought to be the key downstream product of Atg7, only affects autophagosome size, not autophagosome number.  This suggests that Atg7 or its downstream products must have additional, currently unknown roles in autophagy. 

Broader Impacts: strengthening America's STEM workforce via undergraduate research

Hands-on experience with genuine scientific research provides students with training in problem solving skills that they cannot get by merely following established procedures in traditional lab classes.  This experience thus directly contributes to the abilities of the USA's STEM workforce.  This training is particularly valuable for students at Eastern Michigan University (EMU) as it as a primarily undergraduate institution focused on education rather than research.  EMU is an "institution of opportunity" for many underserved students, educating a diverse student body that includes many first-generation college students, Pell grant recipients, and students from various underrepresented minorities.

Over the course of this project, 20 undergraduate research students and three Master's students have received hands-on mentored research training in our research lab, many for multiple semesters.  These students came from a variety of backgrounds, and included underserved racial minorities, first generation college students, and older students returning to college to undertake a STEM education.  Almost all (22 out of 23) of these students were able to present their research as talks or posters at university-wide events, and 12 of them were able to present (individually or in teams) at national or international conferences.  Of the 18 students who have now graduated from EMU, nine are employed as biochemists or chemists in industrial or academic labs, while three are pursuing other careers.  Nine are engaged in further education: four in PhD programs (including one who is an NSF GRFP recipient), three in Master's programs (including two of those currently employed), and one in medical school.

In addition to these students, this research was brought to ~40 additional students through four iterations of an upper-level biochemistry laboratory that I ran as course-associated undergraduate research experience.  Students in that lab worked on genuine research problems (primarily attempts to optimize the expression and purification of Atg11) while also writing mock grant proposals on their own original research ideas.  Overall, this project has provided meaningful participation in scientific research to many students at EMU who may not otherwise have had that opportunity, thus providing them with the skills and experience they needed to help build a stronger and more diverse STEM workforce.     

 


Last Modified: 11/17/2021
Modified by: Steven K Backues

Image
  • Tyrosine 565 is critical to the function of Atg11; its mutation to a glutamate disrupts the ability of Atg11 to dimerize, organize its protein partners (Atg1 and Atg9) and promote selective autophagy.
    Steven Backues
    Copyrighted
    Steven K Backues
    Atg11 mutation effects
